questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Fracture Risk assessment tool

Explanation:

FRAX (Fracture Risk assessment tool):

  • Purpose:
    • Predicts the 10-year risk of major osteoporotic fractures and hip fractures.
    • Helps guide treatment decisions in osteoporosis management.
  • Parameters Used:
    • Age: Older age increases fracture risk.
    • Sex: Women generally have a higher risk due to lower bone density.
    • Height and weight
    • Previous fracture: A history of previous fractures, especially after the age of 50, increases the risk.
    • Parental hip fracture: A family history of hip fractures in a parent increases the risk.
    • Smoking history: Smoking is a risk factor for lower bone density and higher fracture risk.
    • Glucocorticoid use: Long-term use of corticosteroids weakens bones, increasing fracture risk.
    • Rheumatoid arthritis: This autoimmune condition is associated with increased fracture risk due to both inflammation and the use of medications like steroids.
    • Alcohol consumption: Excessive alcohol intake (more than 3 drinks per day) increases fracture risk.
    • Bone mineral density (BMD): If available, a BMD measurement at the femoral neck or spine can be included to refine risk. A lower BMD increases the risk of fractures.
  • BMD in calculation:
    • Without BMD: FRAX can calculate the fracture risk using only the clinical risk factors.
    • With BMD: FRAX provides a more accurate risk estimate by combining clinical factors with the actual BMD value (T-score).
  • Output:
    • The FRAX tool generates a percentage probability of having a major osteoporotic fracture or a hip fracture in the next 10 years, also provides both absolute risk and relative risk compared to the general population.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought with bow legs and on x-ray of wrist following were the findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer (A)Rickets

  • Rickets is caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to defective bone mineralization.
  • The X-ray shows fraying, cupping, and splaying of the metaphysis, along with widened growth plates, which are hallmark signs.
  • Clinically, the child presents with bow legs (genu varum) due to weakened bone structure.
  • Management includes vitamin D and calcium supplementation with dietary improvements.

 

Radiological Changes:

  • Decreased Calcification: Leads to the thickening of the growth plate.
  • Fraying: Initial change is the loss of the normal zone of provisional calcification adjacent to the metaphysis, which appears as a blurring or frayed appearance of the metaphyseal margin.
  • Cupping: Edge of the metaphysis changes from a convex or flat surface to a more concave surface, particularly noticeable at the distal ends of the radius, ulna, and fibula.
  • Splaying: Cartilage hypertrophy leads to the widening of the growth plate resulting in the widening (splaying) of the metaphyseal ends.
  • Generalized reduction in bone density: Osteopenia
  • Widening of the Metaphysis

 

 

Scurvy (Option B):

 

  • X-ray findings include white line of Frankel (dense metaphyseal line), Wimberger's ring (peripheral epiphyseal calcification), and Pelkan spurs (metaphyseal beaks).
  • Clinically presents with bleeding gums, perifollicular hemorrhages, and poor wound healing.

Option C: Hypophosphatemia (Vitamin D–resistant Rickets)

  • Can mimic rickets radiologically but is associated with low serum phosphate and normal/low calcium.
  • Typically presents with persistent rickets despite vitamin D therapy.
  • Not a more common cause than Vitamin D deficiency rickets in india

Option D: None

  • Incorrect, as the X-ray and clinical findings clearly indicate rickets.

questions.text: A child presents with growth failure. Biochemical analysis shows normal ca2+, normal PTH, reduced phosphate, and increased ALP. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hypophosphatemic Rickets:

  • The biochemical findings of reduced phosphate and increased ALP with normal calcium and normal PTH are characteristic of hypophosphatemic rickets. This condition results from a defect in renal phosphate reabsorption, leading to low phosphate levels despite normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels

Incorrect Options

Option A - Nutritional Rickets:

  • Cause: Typically due to a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.
  • Biochemical Profile: Often presents with low calcium, high phosphate, and elevated ALP.

Option C - Type 1 Vitamin D Dependent Rickets (VDDR Type 1):

  • Cause: Due to a deficiency in 1-alpha-hydroxylase enzyme, which converts vitamin D to its active form.
  • Biochemical Profile: Typically presents with low calcium, low phosphate, and elevated PTH, along with increased ALP.

Option D -Type 2 Vitamin D Dependent Rickets (VDDR Type 2):

  • Cause: Due to a receptor defect that impairs the action of active vitamin D on bone.
  • Biochemical Profile: May show normal or high calcium, low phosphate, elevated PTH, and high ALP.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of bone pain for several months. His X-ray skull is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Paget’s disease

Explanation:

  • Paget’s disease is characterized by the progressive replacement of normal bone with disorganized, vascular, spongy bone, resulting from excessive osteoclastic activity followed by increased osteoblastic activity. It presents with a distinctive "cotton wool" appearance on an X-ray of the skull.

 

Clinical Features of Paget’s disease:

Asymptomatic in most cases: Often discovered incidentally via X-rays or elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP).

Symptoms:

  • Persistent, dull aching pain, which worsens at night or in warmth.
  • Deformities:
    • Lower limb deformities: Tibia bows anteriorly, femur anterolaterally, resulting in a thickened, bent limb.
    • Skull involvement:
      • Enlargement may cause tight-fitting hats.
      • Skull base flattening (platybasia) - gives a shortened neck appearance.

X-ray Findings in Paget's Disease of Bone:

Flame shaped lucency of tibia

Disease Phase

X-ray Findings

Early (osteolytic) phase
  • Localised bone resorption often appears as "flame-shaped" lesions along the bone shaft. (Option C)
  • The skull may show osteoporosis circumscripta (well-defined areas of bone loss).

Later stages
  • Bone thickening and sclerosis with coarse trabecular patterns.
  • Stress fractures are visible as fine cracks on the convex surface of long bones.
  • Pathological fractures may be present.”

 

Looser zones : Looser zones, also known as pseudofractures, are characteristic of osteomalacia or rickets. These are incomplete fractures due to defective bone mineralisation.

Sunburst pattern : This is seen in osteosarcoma, where aggressive bone growth produces a characteristic spiculated appearance due to new bone formation.

Ground-glass appearance: This is typically associated with fibrous dysplasia, where bone appears hazy due to disorganised fibrous tissue replacing normal bone.

 

Osteosarcoma (Options A) presents with symptoms of persistent knee pain and swelling, with pain worsening at night and not relieved by NSAIDs. Biopsy shows pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and bizarre giant cells producing unmineralised osteoid

Osteochondroma (Options B) presents with hard mass over the right tibia, imaging showing a sessile growth, and a biopsy showing a cartilage cap

Ewing’s sarcoma (Options D) usually affects patients younger than 20 years of age and usually arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is seen in rickets?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Vitamin D

Explanation:

  • Vitamin D deficiency is associated with Rickets

 

Feature

Calcipenic Rickets

Cause

Inadequate calcium intake (often vitamin D deficiency)

Calcium Status

Low calcium absorption leads to hypocalcemia

Phosphate Status

Hypophosphatemia due to a decrease in tubular phosphate resorption.

Pathophysiological Mechanism

Activation of the parathyroid–bone axis for calcium preservation

Associated Conditions

Primarily linked to vitamin D deficiency

Effect on Growth Plate

Reduced apoptosis of hypertrophic chondrocytes due to hypophosphatemia

 

Options A, B & C: Vitamin A, Vitamin B & Vitamin C are not associated with Rickets.

questions.text: What treatment would you provide to a 60-year-old female patient who had a Colles' fracture 8 months ago, has a T score of -2.5, attained menopause at 52 years, and is currently not experiencing any symptoms, when she visits the orthopedics outpatient department?
questions.solution:
The woman is likely to be suffering from osteoporosis. T score of -2.5 indicates osteoporosis.

In postmenopausal women, bisphosphonates like Alendronate are the first management line.

 

Osteoporosis:

  • Disorder with low bone mass and structural defects, increasing fracture risk.
  • Cancellous regions: More porous; cortices: Thinner.
  • Loss of bone strength is mainly due to decreased bone mass and structural connectivity in trabecular bone.
  • Plain radiographs: Not sufficient for diagnosis, though signs like trabecular loss and vertebral compression fractures can suggest osteopenia.

DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry):

  • T-score: Standard deviations below the young adult mean.
  • Z-score: Standard deviations below the age-matched mean.
  • WHO T-score interpretation:
    • Osteoporosis: Below -2.5
    • Osteopenia: Between -1.0 and -2.5
    • Normal bone mass: Above -1.0

Drugs used in Osteoporosis:

 

Pharmacological Agent

Mechanism of Action

Bisphosphonates (Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate)

Interfere with osteoclast activity, leading to decreased bone resorption.

Calcitonin

Inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption.

Denosumab

It inhibits the RANK ligand, essential for osteoclast formation and function.

Estrogen/Raloxifene

Inhibit osteoclast activity and slow bone loss.

Cinacalcet

Indirectly reduces bone resorption by lowering PTH levels.

Teriparatide

A recombinant form of PTH stimulates osteoblast activity.

Strontium Ranelate

Dual action: It promotes bone formation by stimulating osteoblasts and decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity.

Hormone Replacement Therapy (Option A) Estrogen has been proven to halt the loss of bone mass in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis; however, due to side effects, it is not the first line of management of osteoporosis.

Calcium and Vitamin D (Option C) alone is not found to be beneficial for the treatment of osteoporosis. They can be used along with osteoporosis treatments.

Repeat DEXA scan after 3 Months (Option D) Since there is a clear-cut diagnosis of osteoporosis in this case scenario, along with a history of college fracture 8 months back, alendronate can be started immediately instead of waiting for a repeat DEXA scan after 3 months.

questions.text: What is a characteristic feature observed in osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Normal calcium and normal ALP

Explanation:

  • Osteoporosis occurs due to excessive bone resorption compared to bone formation resulting in reduced bone density.

 

Osteoporosis:

  • Disorder with low bone mass and structural defects, increasing fracture risk.
  • Cancellous regions: More porous; cortices: Thinner.
  • Loss of bone strength is mainly due to decreased bone mass and structural connectivity in trabecular bone.
  • Plain radiographs: Not sufficient for diagnosis, though signs like trabecular loss and vertebral compression fractures can suggest osteopenia.

Bones affected in osteoporosis:

  • Vertebrae (Spine) (Most common)
  • Hip (Proximal Femur)
  • Wrist (Distal Radius) (First fracture)
  • Ribs
  • Pelvis
  • Humerus (Upper Arm)
  • Tibia and Fibula (Lower Leg)

DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry):

  • T-score: Standard deviations below the young adult mean.
  • Z-score: Standard deviations below the age-matched mean.
  • WHO T-score interpretation:
    • Osteoporosis: Below -2.5
    • Osteopenia: Between -1.0 and -2.5
    • Normal bone mass: Above -1.0

Additional DEXA Tools:

  • Vertebral Fracture Assessment (VFA): Assesses for vertebral fractures using a low-resolution lateral spine image.
  • Trabecular Bone Score (TBS): Measures bone microarchitecture based on lumbar spine texture.

Fracture Risk Assessment:

  • Bone density is one risk factor; other tools (FRAX, QFracture) assess fracture risk based on clinical factors and bone density.

 

Normal calcium and increased ALP (Option A)It is observed in Paget’s disease and Rickets or osteomalacia.

Decreased calcium and normal ALP (Option C) This is seen in hypoparathyroidism, renal failure, and vitamin D deficiency.

Increased calcium and increased ALP (Option D) This is seen in primary hyperparathyroidism. In addition to this, they have high PTH levels.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 5-year-old child who visited the pediatrician due to bilateral knee joint pain, normal bone mineral density, and the provided X-ray image of the joints?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scurvy

Explanation:

  • The child's symptoms of leg pain with normal bone mineral density and x-ray showing White line of frenkel involving metaphysis, suggest a diagnosis of scurvy.

X-ray Findings of Scurvy

  1. Characteristic Lines: Specific radiological lines indicative of scurvy are observed.
    • White Line of Frankel: Dense line between epiphysis and metaphysis. Due to calcification.
    • Scurvy Line: Dense line within the metaphysis.
    • Weinberger’s Ring Line: Dense line within the epiphysis.
  2. Trümmerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  3. Pelkan Spurs: Bone spurs from the lateral border of the metaphysis.
  4. Ground Glass Appearance of the bones.
  5. Subperiosteal Fractures: Fractures may occur beneath the periosteum.
  6. Epiphyseal Fracture Separation.

Incorrect options:

Rickets (Option B): Rickets is a disorder caused by vitamin D deficiency or impaired metabolism, leading to impaired mineralization of growing bones. It typically presents with skeletal deformities, including bowing of the long bones, widening of the wrist and ankle joints, and rachitic rosary (enlargement of the costochondral junction). The X-ray findings in rickets include cupping and fraying of the metaphyses, known as "cupping and fraying" or "squared-off" appearance.

Metaphyseal dysplasia (Option C): Metaphyseal dysplasia is a group of rare genetic disorders that primarily affect the metaphyseal regions of long bones. The X-ray findings in metaphyseal dysplasia show characteristic metaphyseal changes, including irregularity, sclerosis, and fragmentation.

Pycnodysostosis (Option D): Pycnodysostosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by impaired osteoclast function, leading to increased bone density and brittle bones. The X-ray findings in pycnodysostosis include increased bone density, thickened cortices, and shortened, stubby fingers.

questions.text: Diagnosis of Gout is confirmed by which test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Synovial Fluid Analysis

Explanation:

Gout

  • Inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and tissues due to hyperuricemia

Clinical Presentation:

  • Acute Gouty Attack- Sudden onset of intense joint pain, typically affecting the big toe, but can also involve other joints such as the ankle, knee, wrist, or elbow
  • Chronic Gout- Recurrent attacks of joint inflammation, development of tophi (deposits of urate crystals) in joints and soft tissues

Diagnosis:

  • Medical History- History of recurrent joint pain, sudden onset, and self-limiting nature of attacks.
  • Physical Examination- Joint examination revealing signs of inflammation (redness, swelling, warmth)
  • Synovial Fluid Analysis-Detection of monosodium urate crystals in synovial fluid aspirated from an affected joint
  • Serum Uric Acid Level- Elevated serum uric acid levels (>6.8 mg/dL) may support the diagnosis, but levels can be normal during an acute attack.

Treatment:

  • Acute Attack- Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, corticosteroids for pain relief and inflammation control
  • Long-term Management- Lifestyle modifications (dietary changes, weight loss), medications to lower uric acid levels (allopurinol, febuxostat) to prevent further attacks.

 

Serum Uric Acid Level (Option A): While elevated serum uric acid levels are often seen in individuals with gout, they are not sufficient to confirm the diagnosis on their own.

Urine Uric Acid Levels (Option C): Urine uric acid levels are not typically used as a diagnostic test for gout. Although increased urinary excretion of uric acid may be observed in some cases of gout, it is not a specific or reliable marker for diagnosing the condition.

X-Ray Changes (Option D): X-ray changes, such as the presence of joint erosions or bone damage, may occur in advanced stages of gout or if there have been recurrent episodes of inflammation over time.

questions.text: Which tumor does not cause osteomalacia and phosphaturia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Breast Carcinoma:

  • Breast carcinoma, or breast cancer, is a malignant tumor that originates in the breast tissue. Unlike the other options, breast carcinoma is not commonly associated with osteomalacia and phosphaturia. Breast carcinoma primarily affects the breast tissue and can metastasize to bones, causing bone-related complications such as bone pain or fractures. However, it does not typically produce FGF23 or directly leads to tumor-induced osteomalacia and phosphaturia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that primarily affects the osteoblasts, which are the cells responsible for forming new bone tissue. While osteosarcoma itself does not directly cause osteomalacia and phosphaturia, there have been rare cases where osteosarcoma has been associated with tumor-induced osteomalacia. In these rare cases, the tumor can produce excessive levels of fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23), leading to the development of osteomalacia and phosphaturia.

Option B - Hemangiopericytoma: Hemangiopericytoma is a rare type of tumor that arises from the pericytes, which are specialized cells found around blood vessels. Similar to osteosarcoma, hemangiopericytoma itself does not commonly cause osteomalacia and phosphaturia. However, there have been reported cases where hemangiopericytoma has been associated with tumor-induced osteomalacia. The tumor can produce elevated levels of FGF23, leading to the development of osteomalacia and phosphaturia.

Option C - Fibrosarcoma: Fibrosarcoma is a malignant tumor that originates from fibrous connective tissue. Like osteosarcoma and hemangiopericytoma, fibrosarcoma itself does not typically cause osteomalacia and phosphaturia. However, there have been rare cases where fibrosarcoma has been associated with tumor-induced osteomalacia. The tumor can produce excessive FGF23, resulting in the development of osteomalacia and phosphaturia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with pain in multiple bones and a history of increased hat size. On examination, some bones feel warm to touch. Biochemical investigations show normal serum calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, but markedly elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paget’s disease of bone

Explanation:

In this patient, bone pain, increased hat size, warmth over bones, and isolated elevated ALP with normal calcium and phosphate are classic features of Paget’s disease of bone, indicating increased bone turnover and disorganized remodeling.

  • Paget’s disease of bone is a disorder of excessive bone remodeling with increased osteoclastic resorption followed by disorganized osteoblastic bone formation.
  • Common features:
    • Bone pain and deformities.
    • Increased hat size from skull thickening.
    • Warmth over affected bones due to increased vascularity.
  • Lab pattern:
    • Markedly elevated bone-specific alkaline phosphatase (BSAP) — reflects high osteoblastic activity.
    • Normal serum calcium, phosphate, and PTH (unless there is immobilization or fracture).
    • Urinary markers of bone resorption: hydroxyproline, deoxypyridinoline, C- and N-telopeptides, TRAP, cathepsin K.
    • Possible hyperuricemia due to increased bone turnover.

Osteosarcoma (Option B): Presents with localized bone pain, swelling, and destructive lytic–sclerotic lesions on imaging; ALP may be elevated but not as markedly as in Paget’s unless there is associated fracture or tumor activity. No diffuse bone involvement or hat size increase.

Multiple myeloma (Option C): Typically shows lytic bone lesions with hypercalcemia, anemia, and renal dysfunction. ALP is usually normal or only mildly elevated because osteoblastic activity is low.

Osteomalacia (Option D): Due to defective bone mineralization from vitamin D deficiency; labs show low calcium, low phosphate, elevated ALP, and increased PTH — not the normal calcium/phosphate seen here.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of the noted findings in a 39-year-old male who presents to the clinic for a routine checkup and only exhibits mild generalized weakness without any other symptoms?   	 		 			 			Parameters 			 			 			Values 			 		 		 			 			ALP 			 			 			Normal 			 		 		 			 			Calcium 			 			 			High 			 		 		 			 			Phosphate 			 			 			High 			 		 		 			 			PTH 			 			 			Normal
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vitamin D Toxicity:

  • The combination of high calcium, high phosphate, and normal parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in this patient suggests an excessive intake or production of vitamin D leading to vitamin D toxicity.
  • Excessive intake or production of vitamin D can lead to increased absorption of calcium from the intestines, resulting in elevated levels of both calcium and phosphate. The normal PTH level indicates that the parathyroid glands are functioning properly and not contributing to the elevated calcium and phosphate levels.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hyperparathyroidism: Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to elevated levels of calcium and decreased levels of phosphate. In this case, the PTH level is normal, making hyperparathyroidism an incorrect option.

Option C - Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by decreased bone density and increased risk of fractures. It does not directly cause elevated calcium and phosphate levels, making it an incorrect option in this case.

Option D - Osteomalacia: Osteomalacia is a condition characterized by softening of the bones due to vitamin D deficiency. It typically presents with low levels of calcium and phosphate, as well as increased PTH levels, which are not consistent with the findings in this patient.

questions.text: A 60 year old woman presents with low backache and on a lumbar CT the following is seen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Osteoporosis:

  • Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by the loss of bone density, leading to weakened and brittle bones. The CT image showing biconcave vertebrae is consistent with the compression fractures commonly seen in osteoporosis. The cod fish appearance refers to the vertebral bodies appearing like the skeletal structure of a fish due to the compression fractures. Osteoporosis is more prevalent in postmenopausal women, making it a likely diagnosis in a 60-year-old woman.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Spondylolisthesis:

  • Spondylolisthesis is a condition characterized by the forward displacement of one vertebra over the vertebra below it. It typically presents with symptoms such as low back pain, but the CT image described in the question does not show the characteristic findings associated with spondylolisthesis, such as vertebral slippage.

Options B - Discitis:

  • Discitis refers to the inflammation or infection of the intervertebral discs. While discitis can cause low back pain, the CT image showing biconcave vertebrae is not indicative of this condition. Discitis is often associated with other findings on imaging, such as disc space narrowing or endplate erosion, which are not mentioned in the question.

Options D - Pott's spine:

  • Pott's spine, also known as spinal tuberculosis. Additional findings, such as paraspinal abscess or destruction of the vertebral body, are typically seen in Pott's spine, which are not mentioned in the question.

Correct Option D - Osteopetrosis:

  • Albers-Schonberg disease, also known as osteopetrosis, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by increased bone density due to impaired bone resorption. It results in thickened, brittle bones that are prone to fractures. Osteogenesis imperfecta, often known as brittle bone disease, is a separate condition characterized by bone fragility and susceptibility to fractures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paget's Disease: Paget's disease of bone is a condition characterized by excessive and disorganized bone remodeling, leading to enlarged and weakened bones.

Option B - Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by decreased bone density and increased risk of fractures.

Option C - Osteogenesis Imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder characterized by fragile bones that easily fracture.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with a painless deformity. A radiograph of the child's legs is shown below. The most common cause of this deformity is____.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rickets:

  • Rickets is a condition that primarily affects growing children and is caused by a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. It leads to impaired bone mineralization, resulting in weakened and softened bones. The deformities commonly associated with rickets include bowed legs (genu varum) or knock knees (genu valgum).
  • Rickets-related genu varum (bowed legs) typically presents as a deformity where the legs curve outward, causing a distinct bowing appearance. This deformity is often painless but can affect a child's gait and overall physical development.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Skeletal Dysplasia:

  • Skeletal dysplasia refers to a group of disorders characterized by abnormal bone development and growth. While skeletal dysplasia can cause various types of deformities, it is a broad term encompassing multiple specific conditions. Without further details or specific indications from the radiograph, it is difficult to determine if skeletal dysplasia is the most common cause of the deformity in this case.

Option C - Scurvy:

  • Scurvy is a condition caused by vitamin C deficiency and primarily affects collagen synthesis. It can lead to various symptoms, including weakness, fatigue, gum disease, and impaired wound healing. While scurvy can cause musculoskeletal symptoms, such as joint pain and muscle weakness, it is not typically associated with painless deformities of the legs.

Option D - Blount Disease:

  • Blount disease, also known as tibia vara, is a growth disorder that affects the tibia (shinbone). It primarily occurs in young children and is characterized by inward bowing of the lower leg, leading to a "knock-knee" appearance. Blount disease can cause painless deformities in the legs, but it is less common than rickets in the given age group
